<Link id="l00004" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// See https://llvm.org/LICENSE.txt for license information.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00005" /><CodeLine lineNumber="5"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// SPDX-License-Identifier: Apache-2.0 WITH LLVM-exception</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00006" /><CodeLine lineNumber="6"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00007" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//===----------------------------------------------------------------------===//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00008" /><CodeLine lineNumber="8"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00009" /><CodeLine lineNumber="9"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// This pass eliminates local data store, LDS, uses from non-kernel functions.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00010" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// LDS is contiguous memory allocated per kernel execution.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00011" /><CodeLine lineNumber="11"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00012" /><CodeLine lineNumber="12"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Background.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00013" /><CodeLine lineNumber="13"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00014" /><CodeLine lineNumber="14"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// The programming model is global variables, or equivalently function local</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00015" /><CodeLine lineNumber="15"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// static variables, accessible from kernels or other functions. For uses from</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00016" /><CodeLine lineNumber="16"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// kernels this is straightforward - assign an integer to the kernel for the</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00017" /><CodeLine lineNumber="17"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// memory required by all the variables combined, allocate them within that.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00018" /><CodeLine lineNumber="18"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// For uses from functions there are performance tradeoffs to choose between.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00019" /><CodeLine lineNumber="19"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00020" /><CodeLine lineNumber="20"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// This model means the GPU runtime can specify the amount of memory allocated.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00021" /><CodeLine lineNumber="21"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// If this is more than the kernel assumed, the excess can be made available</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00022" /><CodeLine lineNumber="22"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// using a language specific feature, which IR represents as a variable with</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00023" /><CodeLine lineNumber="23"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// no initializer. This feature is referred to here as &quot;Dynamic LDS&quot; and is</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00024" /><CodeLine lineNumber="24"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// lowered slightly differently to the normal case.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00025" /><CodeLine lineNumber="25"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00026" /><CodeLine lineNumber="26"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Consequences of this GPU feature:</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00027" /><CodeLine lineNumber="27"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// - memory is limited and exceeding it halts compilation</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00028" /><CodeLine lineNumber="28"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// - a global accessed by one kernel exists independent of other kernels</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00029" /><CodeLine lineNumber="29"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// - a global exists independent of simultaneous execution of the same kernel</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00030" /><CodeLine lineNumber="30"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// - the address of the global may be different from different kernels as they</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00031" /><CodeLine lineNumber="31"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//   do not alias, which permits only allocating variables they use</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00032" /><CodeLine lineNumber="32"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// - if the address is allowed to differ, functions need help to find it</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00033" /><CodeLine lineNumber="33"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00034" /><CodeLine lineNumber="34"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Uses from kernels are implemented here by grouping them in a per-kernel</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00035" /><CodeLine lineNumber="35"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// struct instance. This duplicates the variables, accurately modelling their</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00036" /><CodeLine lineNumber="36"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// aliasing properties relative to a single global representation. It also</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00037" /><CodeLine lineNumber="37"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// permits control over alignment via padding.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00038" /><CodeLine lineNumber="38"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00039" /><CodeLine lineNumber="39"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Uses from functions are more complicated and the primary purpose of this</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00040" /><CodeLine lineNumber="40"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// IR pass. Several different lowering are chosen between to meet requirements</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00041" /><CodeLine lineNumber="41"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// to avoid allocating any LDS where it is not necessary, as that impacts</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00042" /><CodeLine lineNumber="42"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// occupancy and may fail the compilation, while not imposing overhead on a</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00043" /><CodeLine lineNumber="43"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// feature whose primary advantage over global memory is performance. The basic</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00044" /><CodeLine lineNumber="44"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// design goal is to avoid one kernel imposing overhead on another.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00045" /><CodeLine lineNumber="45"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00046" /><CodeLine lineNumber="46"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Implementation.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00047" /><CodeLine lineNumber="47"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00048" /><CodeLine lineNumber="48"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// LDS variables with constant annotation or non-undef initializer are passed</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00049" /><CodeLine lineNumber="49"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// through unchanged for simplification or error diagnostics in later passes.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00050" /><CodeLine lineNumber="50"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Non-undef initializers are not yet implemented for LDS.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00051" /><CodeLine lineNumber="51"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00052" /><CodeLine lineNumber="52"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// LDS variables that are always allocated at the same address can be found</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00053" /><CodeLine lineNumber="53"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// by lookup at that address. Otherwise runtime information/cost is required.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00054" /><CodeLine lineNumber="54"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00055" /><CodeLine lineNumber="55"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// The simplest strategy possible is to group all LDS variables in a single</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00056" /><CodeLine lineNumber="56"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// struct and allocate that struct in every kernel such that the original</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00057" /><CodeLine lineNumber="57"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// variables are always at the same address. LDS is however a limited resource</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00058" /><CodeLine lineNumber="58"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// so this strategy is unusable in practice. It is not implemented here.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00059" /><CodeLine lineNumber="59"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00060" /><CodeLine lineNumber="60"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Strategy | Precise allocation | Zero runtime cost | General purpose |</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00061" /><CodeLine lineNumber="61"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//  --------+--------------------+-------------------+-----------------+</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00062" /><CodeLine lineNumber="62"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//   Module |                 No |               Yes |             Yes |</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00063" /><CodeLine lineNumber="63"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//    Table |                Yes |                No |             Yes |</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00064" /><CodeLine lineNumber="64"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//   Kernel |                Yes |               Yes |              No |</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00065" /><CodeLine lineNumber="65"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//   Hybrid |                Yes |           Partial |             Yes |</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00066" /><CodeLine lineNumber="66"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00067" /><CodeLine lineNumber="67"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// &quot;Module&quot; spends LDS memory to save cycles. &quot;Table&quot; spends cycles and global</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00068" /><CodeLine lineNumber="68"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// memory to save LDS. &quot;Kernel&quot; is as fast as kernel allocation but only works</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00069" /><CodeLine lineNumber="69"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// for variables that are known reachable from a single kernel. &quot;Hybrid&quot; picks</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00070" /><CodeLine lineNumber="70"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// between all three. When forced to choose between LDS and cycles we minimise</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00071" /><CodeLine lineNumber="71"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// LDS use.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00072" /><CodeLine lineNumber="72"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00073" /><CodeLine lineNumber="73"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// The &quot;module&quot; lowering implemented here finds LDS variables which are used by</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00074" /><CodeLine lineNumber="74"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// non-kernel functions and creates a new struct with a field for each of those</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00075" /><CodeLine lineNumber="75"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// LDS variables. Variables that are only used from kernels are excluded.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00076" /><CodeLine lineNumber="76"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00077" /><CodeLine lineNumber="77"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// The &quot;table&quot; lowering implemented here has three components.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00078" /><CodeLine lineNumber="78"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// First kernels are assigned a unique integer identifier which is available in</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00079" /><CodeLine lineNumber="79"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// functions it calls through the intrinsic amdgcn&#95;lds&#95;kernel&#95;id. The integer</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00080" /><CodeLine lineNumber="80"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// is passed through a specific SGPR, thus works with indirect calls.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00081" /><CodeLine lineNumber="81"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Second, each kernel allocates LDS variables independent of other kernels and</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00082" /><CodeLine lineNumber="82"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// writes the addresses it chose for each variable into an array in consistent</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00083" /><CodeLine lineNumber="83"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// order. If the kernel does not allocate a given variable, it writes undef to</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00084" /><CodeLine lineNumber="84"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// the corresponding array location. These arrays are written to a constant</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00085" /><CodeLine lineNumber="85"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// table in the order matching the kernel unique integer identifier.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00086" /><CodeLine lineNumber="86"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Third, uses from non-kernel functions are replaced with a table lookup using</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00087" /><CodeLine lineNumber="87"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// the intrinsic function to find the address of the variable.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00088" /><CodeLine lineNumber="88"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00089" /><CodeLine lineNumber="89"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// &quot;Kernel&quot; lowering is only applicable for variables that are unambiguously</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00090" /><CodeLine lineNumber="90"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// reachable from exactly one kernel. For those cases, accesses to the variable</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00091" /><CodeLine lineNumber="91"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// can be lowered to ConstantExpr address of a struct instance specific to that</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00092" /><CodeLine lineNumber="92"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// one kernel. This is zero cost in space and in compute. It will raise a fatal</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00093" /><CodeLine lineNumber="93"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// error on any variable that might be reachable from multiple kernels and is</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00094" /><CodeLine lineNumber="94"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// thus most easily used as part of the hybrid lowering strategy.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00095" /><CodeLine lineNumber="95"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00096" /><CodeLine lineNumber="96"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Hybrid lowering is a mixture of the above. It uses the zero cost kernel</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00097" /><CodeLine lineNumber="97"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// lowering where it can. It lowers the variable accessed by the greatest</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00098" /><CodeLine lineNumber="98"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// number of kernels using the module strategy as that is free for the first</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00099" /><CodeLine lineNumber="99"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// variable. Any futher variables that can be lowered with the module strategy</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00100" /><CodeLine lineNumber="100"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// without incurring LDS memory overhead are. The remaining ones are lowered</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00101" /><CodeLine lineNumber="101"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// via table.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00102" /><CodeLine lineNumber="102"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00103" /><CodeLine lineNumber="103"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Consequences</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00104" /><CodeLine lineNumber="104"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// - No heuristics or user controlled magic numbers, hybrid is the right choice</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00105" /><CodeLine lineNumber="105"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// - Kernels that don&#39;t use functions (or have had them all inlined) are not</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00106" /><CodeLine lineNumber="106"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//   affected by any lowering for kernels that do.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00107" /><CodeLine lineNumber="107"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// - Kernels that don&#39;t make indirect function calls are not affected by those</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00108" /><CodeLine lineNumber="108"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//   that do.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00109" /><CodeLine lineNumber="109"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// - Variables which are used by lots of kernels, e.g. those injected by a</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00110" /><CodeLine lineNumber="110"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//   language runtime in most kernels, are expected to have no overhead</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00111" /><CodeLine lineNumber="111"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// - Implementations that instantiate templates per-kernel where those templates</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00112" /><CodeLine lineNumber="112"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//   use LDS are expected to hit the &quot;Kernel&quot; lowering strategy</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00113" /><CodeLine lineNumber="113"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// - The runtime properties impose a cost in compiler implementation complexity</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00114" /><CodeLine lineNumber="114"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00115" /><CodeLine lineNumber="115"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Dynamic LDS implementation</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00116" /><CodeLine lineNumber="116"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Dynamic LDS is lowered similarly to the &quot;table&quot; strategy above and uses the</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00117" /><CodeLine lineNumber="117"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// same intrinsic to identify which kernel is at the root of the dynamic call</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00118" /><CodeLine lineNumber="118"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// graph. This relies on the specified behaviour that all dynamic LDS variables</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00119" /><CodeLine lineNumber="119"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// alias one another, i.e. are at the same address, with respect to a given</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00120" /><CodeLine lineNumber="120"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// kernel. Therefore this pass creates new dynamic LDS variables for each kernel</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00121" /><CodeLine lineNumber="121"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// that allocates any dynamic LDS and builds a table of addresses out of those.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00122" /><CodeLine lineNumber="122"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// The AMDGPUPromoteAlloca pass skips kernels that use dynamic LDS.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00123" /><CodeLine lineNumber="123"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// The corresponding optimisation for &quot;kernel&quot; lowering where the table lookup</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00124" /><CodeLine lineNumber="124"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// is elided is not implemented.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00125" /><CodeLine lineNumber="125"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00126" /><CodeLine lineNumber="126"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00127" /><CodeLine lineNumber="127"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Implementation notes / limitations</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00128" /><CodeLine lineNumber="128"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// A single LDS global variable represents an instance per kernel that can reach</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00129" /><CodeLine lineNumber="129"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// said variables. This pass essentially specialises said variables per kernel.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00130" /><CodeLine lineNumber="130"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Handling ConstantExpr during the pass complicated this significantly so now</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00131" /><CodeLine lineNumber="131"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// all ConstantExpr uses of LDS variables are expanded to instructions. This</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00132" /><CodeLine lineNumber="132"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// may need amending when implementing non-undef initialisers.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00133" /><CodeLine lineNumber="133"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00134" /><CodeLine lineNumber="134"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Lowering is split between this IR pass and the back end. This pass chooses</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00135" /><CodeLine lineNumber="135"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// where given variables should be allocated and marks them with metadata,</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00136" /><CodeLine lineNumber="136"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// MD&#95;absolute&#95;symbol. The backend places the variables in coincidentally the</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00137" /><CodeLine lineNumber="137"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// same location and raises a fatal error if something has gone awry. This works</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00138" /><CodeLine lineNumber="138"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// in practice because the only pass between this one and the backend that</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00139" /><CodeLine lineNumber="139"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// changes LDS is PromoteAlloca and the changes it makes do not conflict.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00140" /><CodeLine lineNumber="140"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00141" /><CodeLine lineNumber="141"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Addresses are written to constant global arrays based on the same metadata.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00142" /><CodeLine lineNumber="142"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00143" /><CodeLine lineNumber="143"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// The backend lowers LDS variables in the order of traversal of the function.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00144" /><CodeLine lineNumber="144"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// This is at odds with the deterministic layout required. The workaround is to</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00145" /><CodeLine lineNumber="145"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// allocate the fixed-address variables immediately upon starting the function</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00146" /><CodeLine lineNumber="146"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// where they can be placed as intended. This requires a means of mapping from</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00147" /><CodeLine lineNumber="147"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// the function to the variables that it allocates. For the module scope lds,</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00148" /><CodeLine lineNumber="148"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// this is via metadata indicating whether the variable is not required. If a</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00149" /><CodeLine lineNumber="149"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// pass deletes that metadata, a fatal error on disagreement with the absolute</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00150" /><CodeLine lineNumber="150"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// symbol metadata will occur. For kernel scope and dynamic, this is by &#95;name&#95;</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00151" /><CodeLine lineNumber="151"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// correspondence between the function and the variable. It requires the</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00152" /><CodeLine lineNumber="152"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// kernel to have a name (which is only a limitation for tests in practice) and</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00153" /><CodeLine lineNumber="153"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// for nothing to rename the corresponding symbols. This is a hazard if the pass</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00154" /><CodeLine lineNumber="154"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// is run multiple times during debugging. Alternative schemes considered all</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00155" /><CodeLine lineNumber="155"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// involve bespoke metadata.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00156" /><CodeLine lineNumber="156"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00157" /><CodeLine lineNumber="157"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// If the name correspondence can be replaced, multiple distinct kernels that</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00158" /><CodeLine lineNumber="158"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// have the same memory layout can map to the same kernel id (as the address</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00159" /><CodeLine lineNumber="159"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// itself is handled by the absolute symbol metadata) and that will allow more</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00160" /><CodeLine lineNumber="160"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// uses of the &quot;kernel&quot; style faster lowering and reduce the size of the lookup</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00161" /><CodeLine lineNumber="161"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// tables.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00162" /><CodeLine lineNumber="162"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00163" /><CodeLine lineNumber="163"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// There is a test that checks this does not fire for a graphics shader. This</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00164" /><CodeLine lineNumber="164"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// lowering is expected to work for graphics if the isKernel test is changed.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00165" /><CodeLine lineNumber="165"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00166" /><CodeLine lineNumber="166"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// The current markUsedByKernel is sufficient for PromoteAlloca but is elided</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00167" /><CodeLine lineNumber="167"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// before codegen. Replacing this with an equivalent intrinsic which lasts until</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00168" /><CodeLine lineNumber="168"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// shortly after the machine function lowering of LDS would help break the name</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00169" /><CodeLine lineNumber="169"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// mapping. The other part needed is probably to amend PromoteAlloca to embed</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00170" /><CodeLine lineNumber="170"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// the LDS variables it creates in the same struct created here. That avoids the</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00171" /><CodeLine lineNumber="171"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// current hazard where a PromoteAlloca LDS variable might be allocated before</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00172" /><CodeLine lineNumber="172"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// the kernel scope (and thus error on the address check). Given a new invariant</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00173" /><CodeLine lineNumber="173"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// that no LDS variables exist outside of the structs managed here, and an</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00174" /><CodeLine lineNumber="174"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// intrinsic that lasts until after the LDS frame lowering, it should be</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00175" /><CodeLine lineNumber="175"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// possible to drop the name mapping and fold equivalent memory layouts.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00176" /><CodeLine lineNumber="176"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00177" /><CodeLine lineNumber="177"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//===----------------------------------------------------------------------===//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00178" /><CodeLine lineNumber="178"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00199" /><CodeLine lineNumber="199"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="preprocessor">#include &quot;<a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/pass-h">llvm/Pass.h</a>&quot;</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00202" /><CodeLine lineNumber="202"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="preprocessor">#include &quot;<a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/format-h">llvm/Support/Format.h</a>&quot;</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00203" /><CodeLine lineNumber="203"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="preprocessor">#include &quot;<a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/optimizedstructlayout-h">llvm/Support/OptimizedStructLayout.h</a>&quot;</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00265" /><CodeLine lineNumber="265"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// The llvm.amdgcn.module.lds instance is implicitly used by all kernels</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00266" /><CodeLine lineNumber="266"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// that might call a function which accesses a field within it. This is</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00267" /><CodeLine lineNumber="267"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// presently approximated to &#39;all kernels&#39; if there are any such functions</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00268" /><CodeLine lineNumber="268"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// in the module. This implicit use is redefined as an explicit use here so</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00269" /><CodeLine lineNumber="269"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// that later passes, specifically PromoteAlloca, account for the required</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00270" /><CodeLine lineNumber="270"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// memory without any knowledge of this transform.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00271" /><CodeLine lineNumber="271"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00272" /><CodeLine lineNumber="272"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// An operand bundle on llvm.donothing works because the call instruction</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00273" /><CodeLine lineNumber="273"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// survives until after the last pass that needs to account for LDS. It is</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00274" /><CodeLine lineNumber="274"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// better than inline asm as the latter survives until the end of codegen. A</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00275" /><CodeLine lineNumber="275"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// totally robust solution would be a function with the same semantics as</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00276" /><CodeLine lineNumber="276"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// llvm.donothing that takes a pointer to the instance and is lowered to a</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00277" /><CodeLine lineNumber="277"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// no-op after LDS is allocated, but that is not presently necessary.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00278" /><CodeLine lineNumber="278"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00279" /><CodeLine lineNumber="279"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// This intrinsic is eliminated shortly before instruction selection. It</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00280" /><CodeLine lineNumber="280"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// does not suffice to indicate to ISel that a given global which is not</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00281" /><CodeLine lineNumber="281"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// immediately used by the kernel must still be allocated by it. An</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00282" /><CodeLine lineNumber="282"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// equivalent target specific intrinsic which lasts until immediately after</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00283" /><CodeLine lineNumber="283"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// codegen would suffice for that, but one would still need to ensure that</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00284" /><CodeLine lineNumber="284"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// the variables are allocated in the anticipated order.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00285" /><CodeLine lineNumber="285"><Highlight kind="normal">    <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/basicblock">BasicBlock</a> &#42;Entry = &amp;Func-&gt;getEntryBlock();</Highlight></CodeLine>
